LeBron elevated 11.5 feet to block that shot, his head was nearly at the rim.  This is the moment when LeBron passed Jordan in my eyes.  Being down 3 games to 1 and the determination that it took to come back, having back to back 40 point games and then in game 7 getting a triple double to go along with 3 blocked shots, one of which was of the super human variety.  This was not just any team to come from behind on, this was a record 73 game winning team.  Coming back from 3 games to 1 against 73 win defending champion team is like playing 3 straight championship games, because they faced elimination in 3 straight games.  That is the heart of a champion, most teams would have given up being down 3 games to 1.

I wonâ€™t say that I feel bad for Warriors fans - cause they got 3 out of 4 championships against us.  However, both fanbases had massive knots in their stomach, as we watched shot after shot missed by both sides.   Even after we were up by FOUR, I still wasnâ€™t happy till it ran triple-Zs because Curry is so deadly from deep and I just knew that one of the Cavs was going to foul him as he threw up a triple-prayer.   I can honestly say, that if a Championship ever comes back to The Land, it would be incredibly hard to top how I felt about this one. Being down 3-1, against the regular-season-record-breaking, reigning champs - this Finals meant the world to meâ€¦.   I remember watching the Cavs - 9 years prior in disbelief, as a 14-year-old, getting swept by the Spurs in the finals and sticking with this team no matter who came and who left. Never felt so good to finally have a championship from this team.
Cleveland! This is for you!

Boy oh boy where do I even begin. LeBron... Happy 40th Birthday. Honey, my pookie bear, I have loved you ever since I first laid eyes on you. The way you drive into the paint and strike fear into your enemies eyes. Your silky smooth touch around the rim, and that gorgeous jumpshot. I would do anything for you. I wish it were possible to freeze time so l would never have to watch you retire. You had a rough childhood, but you never gave up hope. You are even amazing off the court, you're a great husband and father, sometimes | even call you dad. I forever dread and weep, thinking of the day you will one day retire. I would sacrifice my own life it were the only thing that could put a smile on your beautiful face. You have given me so much joy, and heartbreak over the years. I remember when you first left Cleveland and it's like my heart got broken into a million pieces. But a tear still fell from my right eye when I watched you win your first ring in miami, because deep down, my glorious king deserved it. I just wanted you to return home. Then allas, you did, my sweet baby boy came home, and I rejoiced. 2015 was a hard year for us, baby, but in 2016, you made history happen. You came back from 3-1, and I couldn't believe it. I was crying, bawling even, and I heard my glorious king exclaim these words, "CLEVELAND, THIS IS FOR YOU!" Not only have you changed the game of basketball and the world forever, but you've eternally changed my world. And now you're getting older, but still the goat, my goat. I love you pookie bear, my glorious king, LeBron James.â¤ï¸ğŸ

Im not a Lebron fan. Im so tired of the Goat debate because for me it'll always be MJ. However, I must admit that this ğŸ† win, was Lebrons greatest accomplishment.  Jordan played against at least 10 Hall of famers during his 6 years in the finals(finals only). The most being on the aging lakers (Mj's 1st title). But the fact Lebron and the Cavs were down 3-1, playing against the greatest team in modern history winning 73 games that season, and against a prime Curry, Thompson, Green, and the great role players for golden state, this was Lebrons greatest test, greatest comeback, and one NBA finals series  that was much tougher than any one of MJ's finals series(considering the talent of GS). I have to give credit when credit is due. The fact that Lebron did it with Cleveland instead of stacking up like he did with the heat makes it all that much more special and impressive.  That block was pure determination and Jordan-esque. He earned my respect 1,000% with this one. This finals, he was the ğŸ‘‘. ğŸ‘ Bravo ğŸ‘

Boy oh boy where do I even begin. LeBron...Honey, my pookie bear, I have loved you ever since I first laid eyes on you. The way you drive into the paint and strike fear into your enemies eyes. Your silky smooth touch around the rim, and that gorgeous jumpshot. I would do anything for you. I wish it were possible to freeze time so I would never have to watch you retire. You had a rough childhood, but you never gave up hope. You are even amazing off the court, you're a great husband and father, sometimes I even call you dad. I forever dread and weep, thinking of the day you will one day retire. I would sacrifice my own life it were the only thing that could put a smile on your beautiful face. You have given me so much joy, and heartbreak over the years. I remember when you first left Cleveland and it's like my heart got broken into a million pieces. But a tear still fell from my right eye when I watched you win your first ring in miami, because deep down, my glorious king deserved it. I just wanted you to return home. Then allas, you did, my sweet baby boy came home, and I rejoiced. 2015 was a hard year for us, baby, but in 2016, you made history happen. You came back from 3-1, and I couldn't believe it. I was crying, bawling even, and I heard my glorious king exclaim these words, "CLEVELAND, THIS IS FOR YOU!" Not only have you changed the game of basketball and the world forever, but you've eternally changed my world. And now you're getting older, but still the goat, my goat. I love you pookie bear, my glorious king, LeBron James. â˜ºï¸â¤ï¸ğŸ«¶ğŸ½

In a city where hope seemed as dim as the fog, Lay a yearning for glory, through an underdog. Cleveland, a heart, beaten yet bold, Dreamt of a story, waiting to be told.  In two thousand sixteen, the stage was set, A battle of titans, in sweat and net. The Warriors, mighty, with records shattered, But in Cleveland's eyes, only one thing mattered.  LeBron, a son of Akron, returned with a vow, To lift his city from despair to the now. With Kyrie, Love, and warriors of their own, They fought for every inch, muscle, and bone.  Down three to one, the world said, "It's done." But Cleveland's heart beat differently, longing for that run. Game after game, they clawed back into the fight, A city's dream inching closer, into the light.  Then came Game Seven, a night etched in lore, A seesaw of emotions, the score tied once more. Kyrie's three-pointer, a dagger so deep, Turned dreams into reality, as grown men weep.  LeBron's block, a moment frozen in time, A symbol of hope, of that uphill climb. And when the buzzer echoed, the deed finally done, A city erupted, the impossible won.  The curse was lifted, fifty-two years in the making, Streets filled with joy, the ground beneath shaking. For Cleveland, this victory meant more than a game, A beacon of resilience, forever to proclaim.  In the heart of Ohio, a fire was lit, A testament to never giving up, never to quit. The 2016 NBA Championship, a tale of fate, For Cleveland, a reminder, that greatness can wait.

God still to this day I canâ€™t believe the Cavs won. I was born and raised in Cleveland Ohio and rooted for the Cavs before these finals and I root for them still till this day. This is one of those games that you remember exactly where you were at, I was at my grandmas house and my eyes were glued to the tv while I sat in front of it on the floor . I remember being so nervous and scared that the Cavs were going to lose again because when they lost in 2015 I was devastated so I knew this year we had to win. I and everyone else watching witnessed history live, but as someone who actually is from Cleveland and suffered the lost throughout the years, seeing them finally win our first championship in any sport since 1964 was amazing. I remember the block, the shot, Kevin Loves defense on Curry, LeBronâ€™s free throw and the sound of the buzzer going off better than the back of my hand. When LeBron had that iconic block on Iguodala I screamed of joy and when Kyrie hit that game winning 3 I started to celebrate but I was still terrified, until we were up by 4 points with 10.6 seconds left of the game. The Warriors had the ball with 10.6 seconds left of the the game and Cleveland was up by 4 it was at that moment I knew the Cavs won their first ever NBA championship. The Cavs were the underdogs and they were going against a 73-9 team, no one though they couldâ€™ve came back from a 3-1 lead but as a Cavs fan I knew that the could do it and I believed in them. This game was more than just basketball. This game was history, the first team in NBA history to comeback from a 3-1 lead in the finals, the Cavs first ever NBA championship, Clevelandâ€™s first championship in 52 years and it was the best night of my life. I remember when the clock ran out and the buzzer went off I started to celebrate and jump around, I poured water and beer on me just because how happy I was and I didnâ€™t know what to do. I remember the day after I had to check my phone and see if the Cavs actually won and I was so happy that it wasnâ€™t a dream. To me as a Cavs fan this made LeBron the Goat, he did something no one else ever did. He came back after 4 years and told Ohio that he was going to give us a championship and he sure did. This game made me respect LeBron as a player and person forever and he will always be the GOAT in my eyes. When LeBron left Cleveland in 2018 I wasnâ€™t mad because he gave us a championship like he said he was going to do. In fact when LeBron left I was a big LeBron fan by then and I told my self wherever LeBron goes I go and rooted for him ever since despite heâ€™s not on Cleveland anymore. When Kyrie left Cleveland in 2017 I wasnâ€™t mad because I was great full for what he did for the Cavs and the city and state of Cleveland, Ohio. I also have too much respect for Kyrie and I root for him and his team to this day. Kevin Love is amazing and I will always support him as well. Also I have to thank the Warriors for choking and blowing a 3-1 lead, seriously I really appreciate that. And in wise words of LeBron James â€œCLEVELAND THIS IS FOR YOU!â€

do you know what "goat" stands for? greatest of all time... its not greatest of this generation, people will always compare with past legends, especially if theres someone that went 6-0 in the finals, won 5 mvps, a dpoy, made 9 all defensive first teams, had the best overall advanced stats in nba history, and impacted the game on a global level far more than anyone else has

Â @Someone-hi1ntÂ  The point he's making is that basketball, like other sports, evolves. The game changes, the players become better in both skill and athleticism, and the talent pool gets richer as the game becomes more accessible. As accomplished as the players of yesteryear were, they would not have had the careers they did if they played today. Therefore, there's no point in comparing the greatest players of the past to the greatest players of the present, i.e., LeBron James.

Â @Zion122Â  and the point im making is no matter how good you are, there will always be comparisons made between legends of different eras... "goat" stands for "greatest" of all time... being great doesnt just mean being the most talented, it also means who was able to accomplish the most, who was able to dominate their era the most, and who had the most impact on their sport

Â @Someone-hi1ntÂ  Who you believe is the GOAT is a matter of opinion, so there are no set criteria for it. For example, many people, including me, would beg to differ that impact is a GOAT criterion. I also don't evaluate individual players based on team accomplishments. My definition of greatness is how good a person is at doing something (by the way, talent factors into this definition in the context of basketball because basketball is a sport, so athleticism and other physical gifts are directly correlated with success). Fields of endeavor not only evolve, but people become better at doing things over time, making it intrinsically more competitive and difficult to be successful. For example, in 2021, Michael Jordan said that he would not have had the career he had if he had played in the modern era (2001-present). The better you are at something, the greater you are at it, and the players of today are greater than the players of yesterday, so it's not fair to compare the players of yesterday to the players of today.

God still to this day I canâ€™t believe the Cavs won. I was born and raised in Cleveland Ohio and rooted for the Cavs before these finals and I root for them still till this day. This is one of those games that you remember exactly where you were at, I was at my grandmas house and my eyes were glued to the tv while I sat in front of it on the floor . I remember being so nervous and scared that the Cavs were going to lose again because when they lost in 2015 I was devastated so I knew this year we had to win. I and everyone else watching witnessed history live, but as someone who actually is from Cleveland and suffered the lost throughout the years, seeing them finally win our first championship in any sport since 1964 was amazing. I remember the block, the shot, Kevin Loves defense on Curry, LeBronâ€™s free throw and the sound of the buzzer going off better than the back of my hand. When LeBron had that iconic block on Iguodala I screamed of joy and when Kyrie hit that game winning 3 I started to celebrate but I was still terrified, until we were up by 4 points with 10.6 seconds left of the game. The Warriors had the ball with 10.6 seconds left of the the game and Cleveland was up by 4 it was at that moment I knew the Cavs won their first ever NBA championship. The Cavs were the underdogs and they were going against a 73-9 team, no one though they couldâ€™ve came back from a 3-1 lead but as a Cavs fan I knew that the could do it and I believed in them. This game was more than just basketball. This game was history, the first team in NBA history to comeback from a 3-1 lead in the finals, the Cavs first ever NBA championship, Clevelandâ€™s first championship in 52 years and it was the best night of my life. I remember when the clock ran out and the buzzer went off I started to celebrate and jump around, I poured water and beer on me just because how happy I was and I didnâ€™t know what to do. I remember the day after I had to check my phone and see if the Cavs actually won and I was so happy that it wasnâ€™t a dream. To me as a Cavs fan this made LeBron the Goat, he did something no one else ever did. He came back after 4 years and told Ohio that he was going to give us a championship and he sure did. This game made me respect LeBron as a player and person forever and he will always be the GOAT in my eyes. When LeBron left Cleveland in 2018 I wasnâ€™t mad because he gave us a championship like he said he was going to do. In fact when LeBron left I was a big LeBron fan by then and I told my self wherever LeBron goes I go and rooted for him ever since despite heâ€™s not on Cleveland anymore. When Kyrie left Cleveland in 2017 I wasnâ€™t mad because I was great full for what he did for the Cavs and the city and state of Cleveland, Ohio. I also have too much respect for Kyrie and I root for him and his team to this day. Kevin Love is amazing and I will always support him as well. Also I have to thank the Warriors for choking and blowing a 3-1 lead, seriously I really appreciate that. And in wise words of LeBron James â€œCLEVELAND THIS IS FOR YOU!â€

Kevin love locked up Curry heâ€™s so underrated

SO MUCH had to go right but also alot of big and little plays in that last minute for Cleveland won that title. I know alot of people praise that Lebron block, and then Kyrie's big 3, but not enough is said about the rest.   Kevin Love had an awesome awareness to have the foresight that Curry was going to rush a 3 and instead of waiting, he rushed the basket and secured a rebound. He could have let the ball roll out, but knew it would stop time, instead with CLE securing the possession it allowed them to wind the clock down (Then Lebron missed his hook, but had it gone in. The Dubz were in a bad spot).   In the next possession (Kyrie's 3). JR didn't rush the screen and once he got the switch, he did a quick little shuffle around Klay into the top of the arc but specifically in a range he can absolutely hit from thus forcing Klay to HAVE to stay on him (Good play call by Lu too). You can see as JR is shuffling in the right arc, and creeping - Klay has to turn his head and look at him for a brief second instead of taking the chance to help Curry, and as soon as his head turns back to Steph - Kyrie is going up for the shot. Also, Richard Jefferson waits an extra second before he runs down the block to the opposite corner (even as Kyrie is already starting his size up battle with Curry). Again, that extra second forced everyone to AHVE to pay attention to Rich instead of coming over to help curry at all.   The Dubz got to have their response but were met with wonderful rotation and switching on the Cavaliers end, and obviously Love did a great job defending Curry. Twice in the last 5 minutes did the dubz get that switch and twice Love shut Curry down.   When Irvin rushes down the court everyone else for Cleveland is still beyond the half-court line EXCEPT Love who again had the foresight to walk up and stay in an open neutral area (as we're taught in high school ball to run to the side of the court with the ball NO MATTER WHAT). Had he not done that, Kyrie would have been trapped and likely turned the ball over. This gave Cleveland the ability to drain crucial seconds off the clock, which then led to the foul, and then led to the attempted Lebron dunk turned shooting foul.   All those small things matter. The big plays are the ones remembered, but the small plays are the ones that enable the big highlights to even happen.

if the warriors had chris paul or john wall, or any real point guard during this game, it would have been an easy win for them. he had 2 assists in this entire game. the possession where love defended him into oblivion he had a wiiiiiiide open player and a player cutting to the rim he could have connected with, but was too focused on trying to take advantage of the rules that made him able to look like a superstar and draw contact on love with a 3, missing terribly when love didn't make the contact with him he wanted, and essentially losing the warriors the game.   he's a "point guard" with little court vision and below average talent as a facilitator, and he is a well below average defender who has always been carried by his team's excellent defenders. and people want to talk about him as a goat X'D . you can't have that many holes in your game and be so poor at AN ENTIRE HALF OF THE GAME in defense and be an all time great. he's like steve kerr+, playing during a time when rules were designed to make it easier to make 3's and completely neutering defenders, and for a huge market team with the benefit of the referees and league adoring him. in reality, you swap him out with lillard, or paul, or even harden back then and that team gets better, swap him with any other good shooter, korver for example, and they stay the same. that team won with curry carried on the backs of the work green and thompson did on defense. curry was replaceable, but thompson and green were vital to that team.

5:00 curry has ok-ish foot positioning (besides them being too far apart), encouraging irving to go to curry's left rather than down the center, but no hands! his right hand ought to be in that space in front of irving palm up to discourage him driving to curry's right, which is the point of positioning your feet like that, and to discourage him from switching hands on his dribble or try to cross him over (both of which are things irving is known to love). his other hand is back behind him like he's naruto running XD, while there isn't really a passing lane open for him to block with that hand, he doesn't know that cus he doesn't have good awareness and is positioned awkwardly to see the court anyways (which is admittedly not his fault, just due to where he is and how he is defending), but having that hand up also makes it easier to get it up higher to contest or block a shot, which would at least discourage irving from shooting a little. instead both his hands are in terrible position, and his too-wide stance leaves him unable to move quickly enough to prevent irving from simply stepping to the side and taking a shot. he's too low and too slow to get up and in front of him to contest the shot that is at that point obviously coming, and obviously coming from a step back in that direction, and with his left hand not being where it should he isn't able to get it up to contest the shot, which was the hand he ought to have used as it was closer to irving when he stepped to his right. instead he starts to turn his body more encouraging him to drive, but at that point it makes no difference, and now he has to twist his body to get his right hand up to contest the shot.   i'm not trying to sound like an expert, these are basic, fundamental defense tools that you learn in like middle school. curry doesn't know them, or does but doesn't have the presence of mind to use them properly. he and the warriors get smokes as a result. his lack of defensive skill loses them the game and this series XD

I WAS AT THE GAME: Iâ€™m from Cleveland. There were maybe only 300 Cleveland fans in the whole arena. Why? 4 reasonsâ€¦1) There were only connecting flights from Cleveland to Oakland/San Francisco (no direct flights). 2) Tickets were INSANELY expensive.  3) If they lost, it would be a VERY depressing flight homeâ€¦with a connector. 4) They are playing Game 7 in Golden Stateâ€¦the team that had the best record in NBA history. That said, it was a very high risk, high reward scenario.  I spent $3,000 for an 18th row ticket.  My heart raced the entire game. Didnâ€™t eat and maybe took a sip of water all 48 minutes (severe dry mouth).  Fast forward to when Kyrie hit the go-ahead 3 pointer (5:03)â€¦this 65 year old woman, only fan near me, from Cleveland (I never met before) literally pulled an Elaine Benes and pushed me so hard and starting shaking me with complete and utter shockâ€¦â€Holy sh*tâ€¦we may actually win this thing.â€â€¦and sure enoughâ€¦.I took a $3000 risk on the greatest NBA game of all time. ğŸ˜Š PS: My profile pic is me at the game wearing the CLE shirt.

Meanwhile during the final moments of Game 7 of the NBA 2016 Finals... Mike Breen: 6.5 seconds remain on the clock here in the fourth quarter as the Cleveland Cavaliers lead 123-89, thanks to their feminine friend, Temporary Cleveland Cavalier #26, Queen Madame Ninja Barrett. Not much is known about this sports star from the wrestling circuit other than her ability to predict the movements and read the patterns of her opponents. Queen Madame Ninja Barrett: (with the basketball in her possession.) Okay. You can do this, Ninja. Time to send the Cleveland Curse running for the hills. I have to be mindful, though. There's only 6 seconds left, after all. (readying her special shot as she channels her heart and soul into the ball.) All of Cleveland's pain, heartache, sorrow, agony, strife, anguish, heartbreak, torment, all 52 years of it, it officially dies tonight! Let my purification and revitalization reign over Cleveland. unleashes a Super Saiyan scream (goes Super Saiyan, much to the surprise of both teams.) Alright. Let's see if you can handle this. I'll be the one to reverse this. Me. Me! I'm going to defeat you. Time to shift the dynamic of Cleveland, provide a miracle for the first time since '64, return the city to it's former glory, change it's fate, quench this drought, erase the 52 years bad luck and rewrite history. I'm calling this one the Curse Breaker's Drought Quenching Kiss of Death.  Mo Williams: (watches as she prepares to throw her special shot.) Oh my word. Oh, she's a god if she makes this. Ninja: (throws her special shot from the half court and watches as it goes in.) Okay. Hopefully, that should do it. Mike: It's now 126-89. I don't know what happened, but the Cavaliers have now soared into a staggering lead. buzzer sounds Mike: It's over. It's over. Cleveland's a city of champions once again. The Cavaliers are NBA Champions. Cleveland's long sports nightmare has ended. The drought is over. 52 years, time to celebrate a title. Ninja: (as she transforms back to normal, gracefully drops the basketball onto the court and dusts off her hands.) blows the smoke from her hands Well, I'm sure this'll make for an interesting MVP conversation. chuckles to herself (sees her fellow Cleveland Cavaliers approaching her.) Oh. I take it this means the Cleveland Curse is broken? Kevin Love: I guess so. Isiah Thomas: Well, you certainly gave the Warriors a show they'll never forget. Kyrie Irving: Judging by your performance, I won't put it past you if you somehow manage to beat LeBron James for Finals MVP. Ninja: No, I've got a feeling that he'll still get that accolade in the end. You figure, there was a letter that he wrote to his fans 2 years ago that made it clear that he was coming home to bring Cleveland a championship. So, based on that, he's still got a slight edge against me, but we'll see what my dear friend, NBA Commissioner, Adam Silver has to say. J.R. Smith: Oh, that's true. Tristan Thompson: Wait. So, how many points did you end up getting us? Ninja: (points at the final scoreboard.) Look at the final score and be thankful you guys have me on a temporary Cavaliership. All: (look at the final score.) Whoa. Kevin: Okay. I did the math and looks like she extended our lead by 37 points. Ninja: Yep. Hey, wait a minute. Where's LeBron? Kevin: (points to him on his knees.) Oh, he's over there letting his emotions let loose knowing that he finally fulfilled his promise to the city that drafted him all those years ago. Ninja: I see. Mike: And the emotions for LeBron James who delivers on his promise to come home and bring a championship to his beloved hometown and of course the disappointment, the stunning disappointment on the other end. James Jones, his long time teammate, whoâ€™s been with him through all 6 consecutive finals and an emotional Tyronn Lue. LeBron James: Oh my god. James Jones: (approaches and embraces her.) You did it, kid. You did it. You helped us break the Cleveland Curse. Ninja: I'm kind of aware of this. Now, can you please let me approach your teammate so I can comfort him? James: Oh, certainly. Ninja: Thank you. (approaches, takes him in her arms, holds and comforts him.) LeBron: Kid, you absolutely killed it. Ninja: Thank you, Monsieur James. Well, I've got a feeling that my Lone Wolf boyfriend and SmackDown tag partner will probably be here soon. I probably should let Commissioner Silver know to be expecting him. (texts her dear friend, the NBA Commissioner to let him know to expect the Lone Wolf.) There we go. The message has been sent. I think I'm gonna stick around for the trophy presentation and then just go. Iman Shumpert: Alright. Richard Jefferson: Okay. Channing Frye: Well, kid. That was certainly an impressive showing. Matthew Dellavedova: So, what exactly brought you to Cleveland? Ninja: Fate and a desire to learn more about the Cleveland Curse as I've recently grown interested in learning about sports related curse phenomenons in certain cities and certain states. Meanwhile at the front entrance of the Oracle Arena... AJ Hawk: (in the car to the Lone Wolf.) Alright, man. I think this is where you get off. Baron Corbin: (exits the car.) Keep the car running. AJ: Got it. Baron: (enters the arena, clearly ready to begin his hunt for his Lone Wolfess.) Alright. I'm here, my Lone Wolfess. Where are you? (notices another man approaching him.) Oh, looks like this man's a friend of my Lone Wolfess. Adam Silver: Welcome. I am NBA Commissioner, Adam Silver. I take it you must be Ninja's lover? Baron: Yes, (as he shakes the NBA Commissioner's hand.) Baron Corbin. Adam: Oh, yes. Ninja told me to be expecting you. You're actually just in time for the trophy presentation. Follow me right this way. I'll take you to her. (leads him to the podium as it's being set up on the court for the trophy presentation to find his dear friend.) Baron: Coming, Mr. Silver. (follows the NBA Commissioner out to the podium as it's being set up on the court for the trophy presentation in order to find his Lone Wolfess.) Yeah. I deeply apologize for bothering you about this, Mr. Silver, but I just want to fetch my Lone Wolfess and bring her back to Las Vegas so she can wrap up Money In The Bank. Adam: It's no problem at all, sir. (to the Lone Wolf as they enter the basketball court, ready to locate their feminine friend.) By the way, since youâ€™re here, would you like to witness the trophy presentation? Baron: Sure. Queen Madame Ninja Barrett: (notices the two men as she changes back into her normal attire and motions them over to where she is.) Baron: Oh, there you are, my Lone Wolfess. As soon as we witness the trophy presentation, you and I need to head back over to Money In The Bank in Las Vegas. Ninja: Understood. Mike Breen: What a scene, an emotional scene for LeBron James. These diehard fans, so passionate. They so love their teams, decades of heartbreak of being teased, but it never diminished their passion and now, theyâ€™re rewarded with an NBA Championship. As always, the terrific sportsmanship. So much more to come here from Oracle Arena as LeBron James and the Cavaliers win the NBA Championship and the celebration just underway in the city of Cleveland. Letâ€™s go to Doris. Doris Burke: Mike, overcome with emotion is exactly how I would describe LeBronâ€™s reaction as he shares a hug with Kyrie. Iâ€™ll give him a minute, but heâ€™s still crying tears (as someone bumps into her.) of joy. (approaches him.) LeBron. Kyrie Irving: Oh, Iâ€™m sorry, Doris. Doris: No, no worries, Kyrie. LeBron, as soon as that buzzer sounded, your emotions let loose. Can you describe what youâ€™re feeling right now? LeBron James: I set out a goal, two years. I gave everything that I have. I put my heart and my blood and my sweat and my tears in this game and against all odds, against all odds, I donâ€™t know why we want to take the hardest road. I donâ€™t know why the man above gave me the hardest road but thereâ€™s nothing the man above going to put new situations that you canâ€™t handle. And I just kept the same, positive at attitude like, instead of saying why me? I was saying this is what he wanted me to do. Cleveland, this is for you! Doris: LeBron, you did what no other team had been able to do, coming back from a 3-1 deficit in the Finals and to do that, you had to win twice in a place that proved too much for so many teams. What did you find in Game 5 here? LeBron: Just locked in. I had to change my approach a little bit on how I approach the game. I wasnâ€™t that good in the first two games here in this building. I watched a lot of film, detailed it out, changed my blueprint and was able to put together some spectacular games after being down 3-1. History, we in the record books. We the first team ever to come back from a 3-1 deficit. This is special. Doris: Weâ€™ll see you in a few minutes on the podium for the trophy presentation. LeBron: Alright. Thank you, Doris. Mike: One of the great storybook endings in all of sports. And it looked like earlier in the Finals like it was going to end like so many other seasons for the Cleveland sports teams with a defeat and a wait til next year. And LeBron James and the Cavaliers win 3 straight, 2 here in Oracle Arena. Has there ever been a player more valuable to his team than James has been in Cleveland the last two years? You think about what he was able to accomplish, coming back to Cleveland, making a statement, taking a team that had been awful the previous four years and flat out got it done. Those four years he was in Miami, Cleveland had the worst record in the NBA during that stand. He comes back, back to back Finals and a championship season for the city of Cleveland. Final score, Game 7: Cavaliers 126, Warriors 89. Weâ€™ll be back to Oracle Arena for the trophy presentation as LeBron James and the Cavaliers win the NBA Championship. Adam: As you can see, there are two MVP trophies on this podium, one obviously recognizing the Finals MVP and the other one for the new category weâ€™re opening up today, recognizing the Curse Breaker MVP. Two years ago, he wrote a letter to his fans in which he said, â€œIâ€™m coming home.â€ And he said that nothing is given to you in Northeast Ohio, everything is earned. LeBron, it was unanimous. Most Valuable Player 2016, NBA Finals. Congratulations. (hands him the MVP trophy.) Now, for the Curse Breaker MVP. Despite the fact that she didnâ€™t get involved until the second half, her multiple Curse Breaker shots were more than enough to break this curse and quench this 52 year drought. (turns toward her.) My friend, it was unanimous. The inaugural 2016 Curse Breaker MVP, NBA Finals. Congratulations. (shakes her hand, embraces her and presents her the inaugural Curse Breaker MVP trophy.) Queen Madame Ninja Barrett: (takes the inaugural Curse Breaker MVP trophy from her dear friend, the NBA Commissioner.) Doris: LeBron, in the letter that Adam Silver referenced, you said that the most important thing to you was to bring a championship to Northeast Ohio. Why was that so important? LeBron James: I understood what the people of Northeast Ohio been through the last 50+ years. I kept it at bay. I never stressed the fact that I didnâ€™t feel the pressure, that none of those things so it always kept me level headed, but I understood what everyone in Northeast Ohio been through the last 50+ years and Iâ€™m happy to be a part of history. I canâ€™t wait to get back home. Iâ€™m ready to get to you guys. Doris: What kind of character did it require of a group that had so many playing in their first NBA Finals to come out and win on this floor? LeBron: Weâ€™ve been through so much adversity these last two years. I just knew what we was capable of, even being down 3-1 versus the greatest regular season team ever. You know, 73-9 and everybody counted us out and thatâ€™s where we strive most when everybody counted us out and thatâ€™s definitely where I strive the most when everyone counted me out. Doris: LeBron, you won two titles in Miami and I know they meant the world to you. Why does this one feel different? LeBron: Iâ€™m home. Iâ€™m home. This is what I came back for. Iâ€™m at a loss for words. This is unbelievable. It doesnâ€™t feel real right now. Doris: Congratulations, LeBron. LeBron: Thank you, Doris. Thank you so much. Doris: Kyrie Irving, are you around me? Kyrie, a year ago, you were alone in the hospital room watching your team do battle and try to win an NBA Championship. Can you describe what it was like for you going to battle and ultimately fulfilling one of your childhood dreams you said? Kyrie Irving: History was made tonight, but I mean, that championship team thatâ€™s in that locker room right there, weâ€™ve got to give them a lot of credit. They did an amazing job and for us, it was just about being resilient and coming in to take care of business, but I mean, this is one for the books. Literally, one for the books. Doris: Down the stretch, though, it had been tough at times, difficult series for Kevin Love. The big three was able to deliver. Why was that? Kyrie: Just staying aggressive, sticking to the game plan and executing offensively and defensively, but Iâ€™m glad all the Xâ€™s and Oâ€™s are done and we can celebrate this championship. Doris: Can you describe what itâ€™s like playing alongside of LeBron James and what effect he has on this groupâ€™s ability to be confident that it can win regardless of the circumstance? Kyrie: Best player on the planet right there. As you can see with the Finals MVP, he took us home tonight and thatâ€™s what he does. Thatâ€™s what great players do and he made history tonight. And Iâ€™m proud of him. Doris: Congratulations. Tristan Thompson. I donâ€™t know many guys, Tristan, that would embrace so readily the dirty work that you pursue on a nightly basis. Why? Why are you so able to embrace that role? Tristan Thompson: Itâ€™s a starting role. I like to look at a championship team as a puzzle. Everyone has, you know, the roles. Some guys score, the fan and for me, just do the dirty work and just be a starting role. Doris: You told us yesterday that your Father is responsible for the toughness that you display and it is Fatherâ€™s Day and he canâ€™t be here, but I know heâ€™s watching. What would you say to him? Tristan: Thank you for everything, just the toughness, the work ethic he instilled in our family. I love you, Pops. Doris: Iâ€™ll put the same question to you. Youâ€™re playing alongside a once in a generation player in LeBron James. What makes this man so great? Tristan: Michael Jackson said heâ€™s a bad, bad man, Doris. Just how heâ€™s able to elevate everyoneâ€™s game and just help us young guys, show us what it takes to win a championship. Doris: Congratulations, Tristan. And congratulations to the 2016 NBA Champions, Cleveland Cavaliers. Baron Corbin: Okay. I think maybe we should go. Ninja: Right. Well, I'd hate to take the inaugural Curse Breaker MVP trophy and go, but let's just say that I have some business to attend to on the squared circle home front. Both: (leave the basketball court.)

After the events of Game 7 of the NBA 2016 Finals... Both: (arrive at the front entrance of the Oracle Arena.) Baron Corbin: (texts his accomplice to let him know that he's with his Lone Wolfess.) Okay. I just texted Mr. Hawk. Queen Madame Ninja Barrett: (with the inaugural Curse Breaker MVP trophy in her possession.) Wait. Monsieur Hawk accompanied you to get me? Baron: (nods in response to his Lone Wolfess's question.) Yes. Ninja: Oh, you and Monsieur Hawk are so sweet. Yeah. I kinda feel bad for Monsieur Hawk right now, knowing that he's going to have to drive home in an insane amount of traffic in Cleveland due to the celebration taking place that'll extend to the entirety of Ohio itself. Baron: I'm sure he'll be fine. Ninja: Yeah. You're right. ???: (approaching them.) calls out to them in a familiar voice Wait. Ninja. Both: (turn to see the NBA Commissioner approaching them.) Ninja: (to her dear friend, the NBA Commissioner.) Oh, Monsieur Silver. Have you come to walk us out? Adam Silver: Yes, I have. Look, I know you're currently preparing to return to the ring as I'm sure your obligation as the premier fighter's calling, but Mr. Gilbert (as he reaches into his coat pocket and pulls out a folded piece of paper given to him by the majority owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers.) wanted me to give you this before you left. Ninja: (takes the folded piece of paper from her dear friend, the NBA Commissioner.) Thank you, Monsieur Silver. (unfolds it and takes a look at it before looking up at her dear friend, the NBA Commissioner in confusion.) What the heck even is this? Adam: Listen, Mr. Gilbert was so impressed by your performance in Game 7 tonight here at the Oracle Arena against the Golden State Warriors that he wanted to offer you an extension of your Temporary Cleveland Cavaliership. Ninja: Well, dang. That's rather generous. (pulls out a pen.) I'll need to borrow a table. Adam: Oh, here. (brings over a small table.) I think we can use this. Ninja: Oh, how convenient. (sets the extension of the Temporary Cleveland Cavaliership down on the table.) Let's just do ourselves a favor and get this over with. clicks pen (signs the extension of her Temporary Cleveland Cavaliership.) There we go. (passes it back to her dear friend, the NBA Commissioner.) Adam: (retrieves the signed extension of her Temporary Cleveland Cavaliership from his dear friend to give back to the majority owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers.) Thank you. So, the extension of your Temporary Cleveland Cavaliership won't come into effect until October. Ninja: October. Wait. That's when the Cavaliers have their ring ceremony, right? Adam: Yes. Ninja: So, since I'm the inaugural Curse Breaker MVP, that means that I'll probably receive my championship ring either second to last or last. Adam: Yes. That's the long and the short of it. We're just not sure which way it'll be yet. Ninja: Okay. Baron: (to his Lone Wolfess's dear friend, the NBA Commissioner.) You know, I think I'm starting to understand why my Lone Wolfess gravitates toward you so much. Like her, you emit a sense of calm and have, in your own way, become like a pillar of strength. Adam: Wow. I guess I really never thought of it like that. Oh, do you both want me to escort you out? Ninja: If you wouldn't mind, Monsieur Silver. Adam: Alright. In that case, follow me. (leads them to the door of Oracle Arena.) Both: (follow the NBA Commissioner out of the Oracle Arena.) Adam: Okay. (turns toward his dear friend.) Well, my friend. The Cavaliers and I will see you in October at the Quicken Loans Arena for the ring ceremony. Ninja: Alright. See you then, Monsieur Silver.  Both: (walk out of Oracle Arena and toward the waiting vehicle.) AJ Hawk: (pulls up to the entrance of the Oracle Arena.) Hey. You guys ready to blow this popsicle stand? Baron: Ready as we'll ever be, Hawk. Both: (get in the car and drive away.) AJ: I can't believe it. The inaugural Curse Breaker MVP. Alright. So, the plan is I'm going to drop the two of you off at the arena in Las Vegas and then just go. Baron: That's fine. Ninja: Yeah. Â @boratwilson9916Â  Where was MJ before 6-0...the same as LeBron, ringless because of a lack of supporting squad. Here's the differences: MJ made six postseason appearances in those first six years. LeBron missed the playoffs twice in those first eight seasons without a ring. MJ lost six series, all as a road underdog. In other words, his teams weren't expected to win...again BECAUSE his team did not have the overall talent to beat two legendary championship teams in the Bird Celtics and Bad Boy Pistons. Never once though, did MJ fail to show up in defeat. LeBron lost THREE TIMES with home court advantage and being a clear favorite twice...against the 09 Magic and 11 Mavs. MJ never scored single digits in the Finals. Or got outplayed in a Finals by a journeyman like Jason Terry. As great as LeBron has been in the last 10 years, it's telling that he STILL only has four rings, when MJ won six the moment HE started to win. Those of you trying to use LeBron having more years actually strengthens MJ's hold on GOAT status because he got his achievements much more efficiently than LeBron did. Six rings, six Finals MVPs, five MVP. Zero home court series losses, zero Finals losses. Y'all try to devalue who MJ beat...because you can't use a loss against him. That's how great he was, dozens of Hall of Famers came at him but could not beat him once he had what he needed. I'm a Lakers fan and have LeBron at #3 behind Jabbar. I have tremendous respect for his game and legacy. But I saw MJ. Not on YouTube, not with a bunch of Gen Z stans trying to slander his opposition...but live. As it happened. I've never seen a player before or since that scared opponents more. Teams didn't really feel they could win, because the Bulls had Jordan. I've never seen that with LeBron.

This series and game solidified Lebron as one of the greatest if the thee greatest player of all time. The highest touted NBA prospect probably ever finally comes back home to the city he once betrayed and was down 3-1 against arguably one of the best NBA teams of all time. All the odds were stacked against them and Lebron instilled this belief that they could win. This series is the greatest testament to Lebron's value. Without Lebron on that team they may have not even made it past the first round let alone make the playoffs. Lebron brings a value to a team unlike any other. He's the most valuable player ever and the greatest basketball player of all time. I will likely get hate for this comment from Jordan stans and Lebron haters. I hope that when Lebron retires the haters appreciate his greatness. As someone once said, "your hate for a player should never exceed the ability to appreciate the game of basketball."

Imagine if there was instant replay in 2015 and 2016.  The story would be different.

June 9th, 2015, I was called in to the hospital because a donor because available.   I remember watching the Cavs win Game 3 in the hospital room and a few hours later, I'm undergoing a double lung transplant.  Cleveland would end up losing the series while I was still in the hospital.  Fast forward a year June 19th, 2016, I was at home sitting comfortably on my couch watching Game 7 and I was so elated that the results this time were very different.  I'll never forget that night.  I was so happy for Lebron and of course Kyrie, Love, and the rest of the team as well.

@Dhk4: LeBron James fan here. I really enjoyed your post. I would like to add some more to it. Speaking of the KG/Ray Allen/Paul Pierce union which essentially created the "Big Three" topic of discussion back in 2008, which led to the Boston Celtics winning the NBA Championship that season, did anyone really seem to complain about that concept at the time? The answer is no. Fast Forward to 2010. LeBron James announces that he's decided to take his talents to Miami and sign with the Heat. Instantly, he becomes the most vilified and hated basketball player in the NBA. Even retired NBA players, most of whom were either Hall of Famers or All-Time Greats, spoke out against him seeking to join forces with two other proven NBA All-Star players, one of which had already led his team to an NBA Championship - that being Dwayne Wade. So, it was all fine and good for Boston to implement that concept and end up winning a championship as a result; but when LeBron James chose to join D-Wade and Chris Bosh in Miami to pursue that same goal, he was chastised, criticized, and disparaged constantly for it. That Miami team went to four straight NBA Finals and won two championships. Ironically, it was one of Boston's 2008 NBA Championship Big Three members, Ray Allen, who himself decided to leave the Celtics and sign with the 2012 defending NBA Champion Miami Heat - joining LeBron, D-Wade, and Chris Bosh for another successful championship run in 2013. LeBron returns to Cleveland in 2014, the Cavs lose to GSW in 6 games in the 2015 NBA Finals with Kevin Love out injured, and Kyrie Irving going down injured in Game 1 - missing the rest of that series as well. That brings us to Cleveland's victory in the 2016 NBA Finals. As a result of that, as you so accurately put it, GSW added Kevin Durant to a 73-9 team to beat LeBron. KD signed with GSW to pursue winning a championship. He got two rings while he was there. Yes, he took some criticism for that, however, it wasn't anywhere near the level that LBJ was subjected to. Your assessment of the Clippers was 100% on-point and laugh-out-loud funny as well. Their "Dynamic Duo" came up short against a talented and very competitive Denver team that did finish as the No. 3 seed in the Western Conference behind the Clippers at No. 2 and the Lakers at No. 1 - with their "Dynamic Duo" of AD & LBJ, plus Playoff Rajon Rondo leading the way to what is about to become the Lakers 17th NBA Championship in franchise history!! Irving's shot was truly amazing.  Consider the context: His team has come back from a 3-1 deficit in the NBA Finals to force a game 7 against a team that just achieved the best regular season record in NBA history. Game 7 is tied with a minute remaining, and Irving has the ball in his hands. He knows this is the most important possession of the game. He makes his move and raises up for a three over two-time NBA MVP Stephen Curry. It goes in. He puts his team up 92-89 with 53.0 seconds remaining.  That was one of the most clutch shots in NBA history. I never get tired of watching it.

As amazing as he is, I wouldn't want the ball in his hands with a minute left and the series on the line. No way. He's proven again and again that he's a finals failure. He missed a couple easy baskets in the last 5 minutes and almost missed that second free throw. Damn is he insecure. And that's why he has to claim and boast that he's the greatest of all time and that his 2016 and 2020 championships are the greatest championships of all time. What a despicable POS to make those claims disrespecting all the greats before him and all they accomplished in paving the way for him to be a superstar. Yep.. One of the greatest moments I had watching a game.. I went to KFC for some wings and I had to game showing on my phone watching it live until I got back home so when I ordered my food (I turned the phone over and black screen the phone) so she can hear my order correctly but at the same time I was hearing people in the background cheering in which I didn't think nothing of during the time.. So I pulled up to the second window cause it's late night and most restaurants would not take money from the first window.. so I approached the second Window and the lady says we are cooking your wings now, it may take 3 to 5 minutes and I said cool.. She was having a little conversation with me or whatever and I hear a dude and a girl say "Did you see that??! Let's Go" I didn't think nothing of it so I'm still running my mouth to this lady and I hear them say "LEBRON JAMES FOR THE BLOCK" and I'm like WHAT????! So I'm trying to see what the fuss is about and unblacked my phone and open up Sling TV and it loads slowly until it got back to ABC and I caught the Replays of it.. and I said loudly "YEEEEESSSSS!!" The lady asked Are you watching the game too?? and I said hell yeah! So I stayed there another 6 or 7 minutes talking until another customer pulled up.. It was one of the best nights of my life.. And this game made it worthwhile as well.. I will never forget it.. It felt so magical that it didn't feel like some thing normal but magical cause at least for once we were all happy about some thing and it felt good about something and celebrated because of it..  ğŸ˜ŠğŸ˜¥ğŸ˜Š

Â @skj_LDN_DXBÂ  Because they clearly were not a 73 win team. They were an extremely pale reflection of that in the playoffs. A true shadow of themselves. Everyone with eyes saw that leading into the Finals if not much earlier. They were a 64-65 win team that was seduced by the chance at history so they played harder than they should  have. This lead to injuries down the line and extreme fatigue. They should have eased into the playoffs by resting starters during the final 2 or 3 weeks by playing them a lot fewer minutes. Instead they won 73, curry got hurt and the rest of the team was exhausted to the point they almost lost MORE games in 25 playoff games than they did in 82 regular season games.   They were so bad in the WCF that if they didn't have a monumental choke job led by durant to aid them they'd likely have lost there. Then coupled with increased fatigue and the fact they were supposed to be up against the greatest player of his generation who finally had help, it should have been a cakewalk for the cavs.  The warriors are not a 73 win team in my book (yes i know the only thing that matters is the straight, unbiased, dispassionate numbers which said they were, but in my estimation they weren't a 73 win roster). They are a 65 win team that massively overachieved in pursuit of history and it cost them dearly. Even had they won the title in 7 games to the Cavs, the sheer amount of attrition suffered in the last 2 rounds precludes them from GOAT talk, which was the whole point of their desire to win 73. It is almost ironic and poetic.

I was at home with dad. He took the night off of work to watch this game.  Everyone else upstairs. We from The Land so we were not missing this game. 10:30 at night yet both of us wide awake, tv volume 33, all we heard was the game. Then we heard was that final buzzer. "Its over........Cleveland is a city of champions". My dad screamed Yes! It was the first championship in his lifetime. The curse had existed as long as hed been alive. Hed seen everything. The drive, the fumble, the shot. I was alive for 97s world series choke.  He screamed it at the tv he kept screaming it over and over. Tears pouring down his cheeks. Its the one of the few times ive ever seen him cry. I tried to keep it together but then he hugged me. And i startedğŸ¤£ğŸ˜‚ğŸ¤£ğŸ˜‚. We watched the whole postgame. We didnt move. We were so overcome with happiness, exhaustion, relief. We feel asleep right on the couch. I will never forget that night. I am eternaly grateful to LBJ and the Cavs and Cleveland sports for giving me that moment. Sports in general had alot terrible teams and expiriences and moments. But the rare good ones will last a lifetime.

In the past, many have made the conclusion that His Airness, Michael Jordan is the greatest NBA player of all time due to many, many reasons. For one, he won 6 championships- won in two three-peats:Â fromÂ 1991 to 1993Â and, fromÂ 1996 to 1998. And while Bill Russell owns the record for most championships won as a player, we have to consider the fact that Russellâ€™s era was simpler compared how the NBA was when Michael Jordan came into the picture. We all thought that MJ being the GOAT was already settled. And not. In fact, itâ€™s one debate in the NBA that will never end and will never be settled. Especially now that LeBron James recently said that his 2016 championship victory over some super team cemented his status as the GOAT. Okay. Letâ€™s put it this way: beating a favored team from a 1-3 deficit might be the greatest comeback the NBA has seen but no, it doesnâ€™t make a player the GOAT. And no matter how die-hard LeBron fans try to debate it, their idol isnâ€™t the GOAT and will never be one.  Ugly Finals Record  3-6. Letâ€™s be realistic here: calling yourself the GOAT with that horrible record in the NBA Finals will make you a fool. As a matter of fact, LeBron James got swept twice in the Finals. The first one was against the San Antonio Spurs in 2007 and the second one?Â Against the Golden State Warriors in 2018. And yet, heâ€™s the GOAT? Really?  Heâ€™s full of himself  One great achievement doesnâ€™t make one a GOAT in any sports in general. In fact, most NBA legends of the past have their own choices of their GOAT and itâ€™s not themselves. But LeBron James? His 2016 victory, coupled by an injury to Andrew Bogut and a Game 5 suspension to Draymond Green, was what made him the GOAT. And the fact that he has gotten his head coaches fired in the past? Well, is that your GOAT, folks?  He will never be the GOAT  He can stuff the stat sheet every game. He can break every breakable record he could break. He could win more championships in the future but no matter what he does, he will never be the NBAâ€™s greatest player of all time. Why? For the simplest reason: that GOAT label has already been taken. And frankly, even some NBA legends donâ€™t think that LeBron James will ever be the GOAT

So by that token Jordan is greater than Lebron on that alone if everything else was even and it isn't since Jordan has more titles, more Finals MVPs, higher PPG, more DPOY, more SPG, etc.  Lebron had a cakewalk to the finals in the East for 8 years propped up by having Wade a top 50 player, Bosh, Kevin Love and Irving. The east was routinely considered much weaker until recently when the Warriors had broken down and lo and behold James moves west with the rise of the Bucks, Sixers and Raptors.   NFL is noted for way more parity while the NBA is routinely scrutinized for its playoff lack of parity. Compare the champions of the MLB, Hockey and NFL vs the NBA since the 50s and you will see why. Point is that it is hard to make claims about Curry or Klay like that. One of the greatest NBA finals ever.  Lebron James "the chosen one" comes back to Cleveland and promises to lead them to the championship, thus ending a 53 year winless drought. The city of Cleveland has never won a championship on any major sports team in this 53 year time period. The Golden State Warriors also had the best regular season record in history, and were up 3-1 in the finals. At that point, no team had ever come back from that kind of deficit.   But despite all odds, Cleveland found a way to win, thus ending the 53 year drought and Lebron James kep his promise of leading them to a championship.   And this is why the 2016 finals will go down as one of the greatest in NBA history.

Contrary to popular belief, these Warriors lost their claim as best team in NBA history when they went down 3-1 to the OKC Thunder. The 1996 Bulls only lost 13 games including the postseason, whereas the Warriors lost 14 games when they went down 3-1.    Additionally, had these Warriors won Game 7, they still would've lost 17 games in total, one more loss than the 2017 Warriors. Although the 2017 Warriors arguably wouldn't have gone 16-1 without KD, who they wouldn't have had without losing Game 7.

T8VIN no one scored for like 5 minutes straight. There was nothing championship clinching about it, just excellent defence like Draymond and Iggy were playing in those same five minutes. The shot is what put points on the boards and the team with more points won that game. When there is a deadlock, the thing that breaks that deadlock is scoring not continued good defence. If the block did not happen, Iggy would have put the warriors up two, Kyrie's shot would have put the cavs back up 1 and then as the cavs would have been leading, the cavs would have had the greater chance of winning from there onwards.

T8VIN indeed and the cav's excellent defence won them that game (that and Curry missing makable shots for him). Defence is done as a team, i.e. the defender who slowed iggy down before the block. Â IamGrandMagusÂ  im a big curry fan but he's not a one on one player. as a matter of fact, any decent long and athletic wing defender can shut down curry one on one in a late game situation. i think its kind of unfair for us to expect curry to just go get the ball and go to work one on one like a lebron or kd can. dude is 6'3 with short arms and very limited explosiveness. other than his handles he doesn't have the strength or quick first step to gain separation. theres this huge narrative about curry underperforming in the playoffs/finals and the reason why is because in the playoffs game gets slower with higher defensive intensity and whistles get tight. curry is not able to get out on the break or play off the ball because all the pulling shoving grabbing just about anything goes in these playoffs. curry gets held by shump on damn near every play off the ball. you might say well why can't he run some pick and rolls? he did, and the warriors got an open corner 3 on every pick and roll he runs because he gets trapped off every single pick. mind you curry is the first player to receive that kinda defensive attention on EVERY PICK, long before lillard, harden, trae young etc etc. the clippers were the first time to do that to him in the first round of the 2014 playoffs. before then, no one, i repeat no one has gotten that kinda defensive attention because you are essentially giving up and open lane for the roll man or an open look from the corner after rotation. WELL this didn't work for the warriors because draymond has 0 scoring ability and harrison barnes couldnt throw the ball into the ocean in that series.  these are not excuses, these are facts. they are also why curry isn't in the goat conversation and lebron is. nobody is saying curry is better than bron. curry maximized his potential and lebron didn't. he's too scared of missing the last shot and taking the blame. its like once the ball is off his hands he's off the hook because he made the "right play" regardless of the shot goes in or not. in a late situation i think most teams rather have someone like danny green shumpert or jr shoot an open shot than lebron putting his head down taking his 260 lbs of pure muscle and bully his way to the hoop, get a lay up or get fouled or even pull up from the elbow if the lane gets clogged. but he too SCARED. it's not like kyrie is getting easy shots down the stretch either. but he has the balls to take and make tough shots and live with the results.

Everyone talks about Jordan because he did shit that no one else did. Well this right here is something that only Lebron will ever achieve. Preserving a chance to seal a 3-1 comeback against a 73 win team to deliver on a promise to your home states team with one of the greatest defensive plays of all time... while leading both teams in every major stat. This is singular and hands down the most clutch any player will ever be in any playoff series. Except maybe... 2007 Lebron against the Pistons. No one will ever know how it feels for Lebron in that moment. Everything must have come out: the scrutiny he's had since he was 15, the struggles to drag nobodies for years, the unparalled hatred and expectations he's endured, and actually leading a 3-1 comeback. One of the greatest narratives in the history of sports and it was a 10 year journey going back to his first playoff game that brought him to this legendary moment.

Gave me goosebumps when I watched it live and it still gives me goosebumps today. This championship win had so much impact around the league, it had so much meaning, lifting the Cleveland sports curse and seeing Lebron fulfill a promise he made to that city... you can't write a better sports story. Cavs came in as the underdog. They had to face a team that many considered unbeatable. A team that broke the single season wins record with 73 wins and single digit losses over an 82 game season. Sure, the Cavs got gifted a Draymond Green suspension. But the Cavs won 2 in a row with Draymond back including a game 7 in the Oracle. They won 3 in a row, 2 of which were on the road. Only team to come back while being down 3-1 in the finals. Unbelievable finish and I never would've expected it. I thought the series was over after game 2.

what the hell is LeBron doing burning shot clock in a tie game at 1:30 left? Tries to bully his way to the basket and misses a 5 jump hook and Iguodala hardly jumps to contest, then flat foots his way up court where GS immediately miss a shot. Now, this next thing I say is the history of Lebron in the end of playoff games. After running the floor for the block he was gassed. The reason he dribbled down the play clock on that play was that he was gassed. the reason he missed the shot was because he was gassed and the reason why after the GS miss Lebon just started walking back up court forcing Clevland to call time out, is because Lebron was gassed. In this whole 3 1/2 minutes, the only thing he contributed was that blocked shot. Cleveland defense had nothing to do with GS missed open three's. It's on GS for missing but everyone knows how fricking rare it is for GS not to finish. Lebron gets his lucky charm ring. It will be his last. GS comes back and spanks his ass 8 games to 1 in the next two playoffs. In 4 consecutive finals, GS is 16-5 against Cleve and the not GOAT.     I know what it's like to be a fan of a player that screws up in big games. I'll call Dennis Eckersley the greatest closer I ever saw despite that on dumb back door slider he threw to Kirk Gibson in the world series. So if Lebron fans like him because they just love watching him play I'm good with that. But you are not nearly greatest of all time with a 3-6 playoff record and so many of them lost because he could not fulfill the clutch role he put himself in. I think Steph is the highest impact player ever. He hits the clutch shots and the stake in the heart threes in all 3 of his championship years. He's 3 out of 4, James is 3 out of 9. That is a hideous difference. Notice the 3. He has the same number of rings. Get it. Even if GS loses to Toronto I'm still going to think Steph is the most thrilling and most fun player to watch I've ever seen. GS lost game 1. Toronto got bounces and made their out of control shots and GS didn't. The series might come down to which team can make the most out of control shots. Nobody is better than Steph at that, and he has a flair for the dramatic. He'll feed other players, like he did feeding clay Thompson when clay broke steps record for 3's in a game, make them better, enjoy playing with them, won't scowl at them on court if the screw up and he'll always be looking for a way to be more creative and do something nobody's done. Lebron once scored 7 three's in a game. Steph has done seven or better 16 times. Let's not forget Clay Thompson who goes on streaks, 11 in playoff game once, 9 two times (steph 9 twice also) and there there is the straw that stirs the drink, Draymond Green. Game 7. Up by 3. 10 seconds left in the game. I'm willing to bet ANYTHING that when LeBron went for that dunk and got hurt, he wasnt really that hurt. I'm sure he had a little pain, but nothing like what he's acting like. He knows that they just won the Championship and all he has to do is make a free throw. He knows that even if he misses both, it's still very unlikely they tie the game. He knows it's pretty much over and that the entire World is watching him on the ground right now. He's probably thinking that he should pretend to be really injured just to milk out some more sympathy and make it look like something big. He's thinking "I did it, we won. Imma lay here for a little while and have my whole team come and try to motivate me. The whole world is watching and when I finally do get up adnmake this free throw to clinch the Championship, everyone is going t see how I did it with a hurt wrist and how I was beaten and gave everything."  I GUARANTEE THAT'S WHAT HE WAS THINKING. THAT FALL WAS NOT THAT BAD.

It's crazy because I'm sure we all watch a lot of games. Whether it's the MLB, NBA, NFL or any other big sporting event. I'm sure most of us watch them all and had a good time. But this game, and the Dodgers vs. Astors Game 5 of the 2017 World Series are 2 games that will stay with me until I die. I"ll never forget the Dodgers coming back in and watching Chris Taylor tie it up with 2 outs in the 9th. And I'll never forget this game. I remember Kyrie hitting that 3 and everyone going crazy, and I remember LeBron James about to dunk on the entire cite of San Fransisco at the end where he got fouled. I remember them being up with LeBron on the ground crying in pain for a while. I remember him getting up and knocking down that first free throw. I remember after that just saying to everyone "HOLY SHIT! HE DID IT! THEY'RE UP BY 4. GAMES OVER. HE FUCKING DID IT!" What a great fucking memory.

They did the impossible against the BEST Regular Season team in NBA History with a 73-9 record, having NOT lost back 2 back games in a year and a half! Being down 3-1 in this series and having to win 3 games in a row with the last two being away at Oracle. So to beat the Warriors 3 games in a row which no team was able to beat GSW 2 games in a row and No Team ever has come back from 3-1 series deficit in the Finals ever. The probability of them winning the Chip after game 4 was .0001% against this Warrior team. And you gotta thank Klay Thompson for this Championship! Because his comments about Lebron after they beat Cleveland in Game 4 saying â€œThis is a Manâ€™s Gameâ€ and â€œI guess he (Lebron) got his feelings hurt!â€ Even I remember feeling and saying â€œYour waking a sleeping Giant and just throwing fuel on the Fire for himâ€. And when they spoke to Lebron about Klays comments he laughed and was SO annoyed by it but only said â€œIts so hard to be the Bigger man and take the High Roadâ€ but you can see in his demeanor that he was fuming and body was filled with adrenaline! Lebrons response was 40pts with Kyrie also putting up 40pts in Game 5. And putting another much needed 40pts up in Game 6 also to push it to a Game 7. And once itâ€™s Game 7, the entire 6 games leading up doesnâ€™t matter. It just became a 48 minute Game of wills and hunger over which team wants it more than the other. Weâ€™ll never again see in our life time a Team in the Finals down 3-1 comeback and win it. Thereâ€™s a reason why they were the 1st and only team to ever do it in Finals history. Even the playoffs, coming back from down 3-1 only happened 11 times including this series and previous series where the Warriors were down 3-1 to OKC and came back to win. So before these playoffs it only happened 9 times out of over 300+ times in series. This will always be the Greatest Finals ever and the 4 consecutive years that Golden State faces Cleveland in the Finals will always be Known as the years of the Warriors vs. the King ğŸ‘‘ Lebron James. And for me personally this 2016 Championship means more than the 3 Championships the Warriors won over Cleveland. It was a 4 year term of the Best Team in History vs. the Best Player in History. Which people will argue over his Finals Record. But remember, he played against these Warriors 4 times, the Spurs 3 times, OKC once and Dallas once. So he played against Juggernauts his whole career, the only blemish I hold against him on his Legacy is his 1st year with Miami where they where up 2-1 on Dallas Mavs and then they sh!t the bed losing 4-2. When they should have won this series and being the easiest opponent he has played against out of all 9 Finals appearances. Well they made up for it the next year beating OKC with Durant, Westbrook and Harden in a gentleman's sweep 4-1. If anything we would have thought at the time it would have been the other way around where they beat Dallas and lost to OKC. Bottom line is he shouldn't have lost to the Mavs. I believe it was the only Finals that his Team was the Favorite going in while all 8 other Finals his Team was always the underdog. So if he would have just beat the Mavs and everything else stayed the same he would have the perfect Legacy and a lot more people would agree that he is the best player that ever played the game. Well, at least in my opinion that is?

Can we all be honest about something here: ppl define superteam as, 3 or more all stars teaming up to win a ring rather than the organic development of a team to elite status. However that definition - conveniently - overlooks said teams record the following season(s) and said individuals actual production when either playing alongside their co-stars or solely w/ role players. This popular definition is used in the nba lexiconÂ onlyÂ to degrade the accomplishments of Lebron James and no one else as the same standard isn't applied to Kevin Durant or the Celtics orginal Big 3. My point is without this popular narrative, looked at objectively in a vacuum lets say 50 years from now, the data will show that Lebron carried a far greater burden than either Curry, KD or any of the Celtics and its being generous to downright disingenuous to label either his heat or cavs as superteams when defining based off record, number of all stars, finals production of co-starsÂ etc. So everyone on here could say whoever saved Lebron's career or he needed to make superteams to win but the data doesn't lie and when all of you grow old and all these ridiculous narratives stop circulating, future fans of the sport will look at the fact that a 73-9 team couldn't beat a team featuring one serial all star and went and signed a multiple time scoring champ and regular MVP contender to beat them. Wonder who they'll be calling a superteam then

Man I still remember everything around this night, and these last few minutes while watching with my family. I was only alive for the LeBron teams, the awful seasons the Browns had, and the chokejobs from the Indians in the postseason, but my dad had been witness of all the horrible luck to Cleveland, to the point that he thought weâ€™d never win something. My grandpa died a month before this game, and he was the most loyal Cleveland sports fan I have ever known. No matter how bad a team played, or how much he hated how they sucked, he watched every minute of every Browns game, every inning of Indians ball, and almost every minute of Cavalier basketball. When LeBron hit the free throw, and my family was jumping around, because we knew they finally ended the curse, the first thing I thought of, was that my grandpa was up in heaven smiling, because they won, or cracking a joke that they couldnâ€™t let him be alive for the title. This will forever be my favorite NBA Game and moment ever. The finals after this were absolute garbage because Kevin Durant ruined the league, and Kyrie became a prima donna, so this would be my â€œseries finaleâ€ of the NBA, the underdogs toppled the evil empire with all odds against them, so millions of people could rejoice.
If you ever meet anyone that says LeBron isnâ€™t GOAT material because of his finals performances, show them this video.

The most legendary finals performance ever. MJ can have his 6 championships, Kobe can have his 5. This one meant more to Lebron and the city of Cleveland than all of those put together. The number of things that had to go right for them to get this win is unreal. They were down 1-3 against the greatest team of all time, the defending champion who had just beaten them, a team that won 73 games in the regular season and dominated the post-season. For it to come down to 89-89 in the fourth quarter of game 7 when no one on either team could hit a shot, 52 years since the last time Cleveland won a championship, 7 years after Lebron left. But had Lebron never left, the Cavs would have never been a lottery team in time to draft Kyrie, and Kyrie would have never had a chance to develop into a star. If the Cavs hadn't started the season so poorly, they never would have fired David Blatt in favor of Tyronne Lue, who was actually a worse coach. But if he had hadn't been the head coach, who knows if Blatt would have had the gall and simplicity to call a basic switch and have his point guard iso one on one against a defensively improved Steph Curry, while completely nullifying the greatest playmaker/player in the world in Lebron from the most important offensive possession of every singe Cavalier's career. Then if Cleveland never traded for Love, he never would have been there to shut out the most unguardable point guard on the planet for the final minute, even though he had been one of the worst defenders in the NBA all season up to that point, and had barely contributed anything to the series thus far. But had he not been so bad defensively, the Warriors wouldn't have thought to switch their best offensive player onto him not once but twice in the final minutes to make something happen. And had Lue been a better coach, maybe he would have made a change, maybe not even leave Love in. And if Lebron hadn't been born in Cleveland, if he hadn't fallen in love with the least lovable city in America, would he have poured his soul into that chasedown block that was less than a millisecond away from being a made shot? Would he have jumped the highest he's ever jumped in his career and almost kill himself on that final dunk attempt leading to the game-winning free throw? This was the most improbable championship of all time, yet it felt like destiny. It's why we love this game.

Facts

â€‹Â @23rubsÂ  You can try to act like LeBron was laying bricks and that somehow defined his whole finals performance, but Lebron also had one of only three triple doubles in NBA Finals history, why the fuck is you tryna act like just because he bricked he didn't get one of the most clutch blocks of all time. LeBron isn't the best player of all time, but he is clutch enough to lead his team to the finals and come back from a 3-1 deficit, which has never been done before. Also, this was against Steph Curry in his PRIME, he had just come off of a UNANIMOUS MVP SELECTION. There are no excuses to say this wasn't one of the greatest finals performances of all time. Not only that, for the whole Finals LeBron and Kyrie together were averaging a combined 53 POINTS A GAME. Kevin Love barely played a role in the 2016 finals when it came to on ball productivity, his usage rate was only at 12 percent. Klay, Steph, and Draymond combined only outplayed them by a combined average of 60 points per game WITH OVER 60 PERCENT OF THEIR TEAM'S USAGE RATE, and that's with Draymond averaging a double double, not only was his defensive presence massive, it was the absolute core of preventing the cavs from winning, and he still lost that finals. Not only that, LeBron averaged the best defensive stats of the entire finals with 2.6 steals and 2.3 blocks a game, in comparison to the big three of the warriors at the time adding up to average only 2.3 blocks and 3.6 steals a night, COMBINED. You might act like people are riding LeBron's dick, but when you look at the stats he deserved this ring and it really is worth more than a stacked superteam that couldn't even show up in the finals. And also, saying that Miami is even comparable to the warriors is just plain bullshit, not only do the warriors have one of the best two-way players in the league in Klay Thompson, they also have a defensive player of the year and easily the greatest three point shooter of all time, who just so happened to revolutionize the way basketball is played. KD got carried to the finals, LeBron carried his team to the finals.
