YESSSS!!!!! God still to this day I canâ€™t believe the Cavs won. I was born and raised in Cleveland Ohio and rooted for the Cavs before these finals and I root for them still till this day. This is one of those games that you remember exactly where you were at, I was at my grandmas house and my eyes were glued to the tv while I sat in front of it on the floor . I remember being so nervous and scared that the Cavs were going to lose again because when they lost in 2015 I was devastated so I knew this year we had to win. I and everyone else watching witnessed history live, but as someone who actually is from Cleveland and suffered the lost throughout the years, seeing them finally win our first championship in any sport since 1964 was amazing. I remember the block, the shot, Kevin Loves defense on Curry, LeBronâ€™s free throw and the sound of the buzzer going off better than the back of my hand. When LeBron had that iconic block on Iguodala I screamed of joy and when Kyrie hit that game winning 3 I started to celebrate but I was still terrified, until we were up by 4 points with 10.6 seconds left of the game. The Warriors had the ball with 10.6 seconds left of the the game and Cleveland was up by 4 it was at that moment I knew the Cavs won their first ever NBA championship. The Cavs were the underdogs and they were going against a 73-9 team, no one thought they couldâ€™ve came back from a 3-1 lead but as a Cavs fan I knew that the could do it and I believed in them. This game was more than just basketball. This game was history, the first team in NBA history to comeback from a 3-1 lead in the finals, the Cavs first ever NBA championship, Clevelandâ€™s first championship in 52 years and it was the best night of my life. I remember when the clock ran out and the buzzer went off I started to celebrate and jump around, I poured water and beer on me just because how happy I was and I didnâ€™t know what to do. I ran outside and and started to celebrate in my grandmas front yard with the neighbors while fireworks were in the background. I remember the day after I had to check my phone and see if the Cavs actually won and I was so happy that it wasnâ€™t a dream. To me as a Cavs fan this made LeBron the Goat, he did something no one else ever did. He came back after 4 years and told Ohio that he was going to give us a championship and he sure did. This game made me respect LeBron as a player and person forever and he will always be the GOAT in my eyes. When LeBron left Cleveland in 2018 I wasnâ€™t mad because he gave us a championship like he said he was going to do. In fact when LeBron left I was a big LeBron fan by then and I told my self wherever LeBron goes I go and rooted for him ever since despite heâ€™s not on Cleveland anymore. When Kyrie left Cleveland in 2017 I wasnâ€™t mad because I was great full for what he did for the Cavs and the city and state of Cleveland, Ohio. I also have too much respect for Kyrie and I root for him and his team to this day. Kevin Love is amazing and I will always support him as well. Also I have to thank the Warriors for choking and blowing a 3-1 lead, seriously I really appreciate that. And in wise words of LeBron James â€œCLEVELAND THIS IS FOR YOU!â€

This is the greatest Championship not just in NBA history but SPORTS history. Hometown hero promises to end a 50+ year curse, does so by becoming the first player in NBA Finals history to lead BOTH teams in every major statistical category, and leads his team to a 3-1 comeback (first ever 3-1 comeback in NBA Finals history) against the team that just set the all-time win record with 73 wins. You couldn't have drawn up a more dramatic scenario, it's a Hollywood movie. This championship cements LeBron's legacy as the greatest player of all time. It's better than all 6 of MJ's rings. He didn't have to overcome these odds. He always was on the superior team and was expected to win.

every chance in hell in fact, and here's why....  firstly this is not the "most infamous curse in sports history" there are many more significant from football and other sports, its probably not even the most significant one in America, Basketball maybe...but thats only really big in one country and not even the biggest sport in US, that title belongs to American football.  its the English top flight - way more popular that the NBA globally, way richer... and its ran for far far longer than the NBA  Its football... the worlds biggest, richest, and by far most popular sport (and even if you dont like it as a sport by every measurement its the Worlds game)...when they won the title, they made world headlines, no one heard about Cavaliers win outside US as it wasn't that big news.  it was won by a team that at the start of the season were 5000/1 to win the title FIVE THOUSAND thats unheard of odds yet they did it over a 38 game season against giants of team like Man Utd, Arsenal, Liverpool...huge teams heard off the World over, (who knows about Golden State or Cavaliers outside of US realistically? not many unless they are specific fans from other countries) and with no draft system or salary cap to help them...all teams have a much closer chance of winning in US sports as they are obsessed with making it as even as possible for all teams so with that in mind...how can this be so historic if its in the leagues interests to make it a level playing field?   Yes Cleveland did well to win...but Leicester were literally no hopers with a budget about a tenth that of Man Utd, Chelsea, Liverpool and yet they actually won it, and with no comparable le bron james type star players, they were most analysts pick to get relegated, Cleveland cant get relegated as there is no punishment for failure in US sports just reward the next year with a high draft pick.   The EPL is the most prestigious domestic sports tournament on the planet, comparing the two is impossible one was a historic upset and sent shock waves through the sporting world, the other was about an already established superstar player going to his home town (admittedly playing fantastic and lifting his team) and winning a national title which created headlines in America, nothing more (and I hate Leicester, that title win was an awful season for me to witness, but credit where credit is due, they were nothing short of sensational that year)  NOT A SHOT BRO? as I've just clearly demonstrated...EVERY SHOT BRO  ;)

It's not a BETTER league -- it's a DIFFERENT league. PER is higher today all-around not because guys are better... but because less focus is put on defense, the 3pt shot is far more used, etc. Much more focus on offense today. You keep trying to justify what you're saying using basic stats that are completely void of context. Idiots like Nick Wright and Skip and Shannon use stats because that's the only way they can justify their opinion as someone who's never actually played the game. That isn't intellectually honest. Competition in the 90's was FAR, FAR superior all-around. Today you only have a handful of good teams.   I really don't need to justify it at this point, but hell...  -Jordan was a superior scorer. At this point, this isn't even an issue of content even with people who say Lebron is a better all-around player. I think Lebron's game is more well-rounded... not because MJ couldn't have been as well-rounded, but because of how he chose to play the game. But MJ is a superior scorer. Period. That's not even an issue I'm willing to debate, because to say otherwise is indefensibly wrong. What, 10 scoring titles to like 1...? In a superior defensive league? That actually had true big men in the paint? While expending more energy on the other end of the floor by actually playing defense himself? And while those defending him could actually be physical?   Jordan was a superior defender. Again - really not even up for debate. Big part of that is a function of the fact that damn near nobody plays hard defense anymore anyway. But the accolades speak for themselves between the two. And all this talk about Lebron being a better defender because he can "defend all 5 positions" is straight up retarded. The only reason he can defend all 5 positions is because the true point guard has totally changed (now a PG is more of a SG too) and the true 5 has virtually disappeared from the game. In today's game, Lebron can surely handle his own on the block (although his footwork offensively and defensively on the block is mediocre at best...because it's never had to be good for him to be successful due to athletic ability). But in the 90's, if you think Lebron could've guarded the 5 spot with true 5's like Shaq or Hakeem or Ewing or Robinson backing him down....? Homie you are on CRACK. By the same logic used in the first bullet re: MJ being able to be more well-rounded if he wanted to, I'm positive that if Lebron played in that era, or if he truly wanted to, he's 100% capable of playing thank kind of tough defense.   -Jordan was a superior competitor. Again, this really isn't even up for debate. Lebron just isn't that straight up killer like MJ or Kobe. I think he's a smarter all-around player than those two, but killer? Not even close. Lebron wants to win. MJ wanted to kill you. He was addicted to not only winning, but demoralizing the competition. There is no discussion as far as who was a superior competitive.   Jordan did it against superior competition. No - he didn't have to get through a 73-win team (because he was on the team running the show like that). BUT -- all-around, the competition was more well-rounded and just plain better then. The east was stacked. Lebron gets to cake walk to the finals every year through who? The Pacers? Bro.... I'm a Pacers fan. Born and raised in Indy. Reggie was my fucking childhood idol and MJ was a thorn in my side. I watched them go at it over and over again. I watched the battles with the Knicks. Today's playoffs don't hold a fuckin candle to those back in the day. Not at all. To say otherwise is laughable. I'll be the first to say that Jordan never beat a team as good as the Warriors in the finals... but if we're going that direction, we also have to acknowledge the fact that he also never lost to a team as bad as the Mavs... and the fact that Lebron's route to the finals has never been anywhere near what Jordan's was year in and year out. No fuckin' chance Lebron has ever had to go through a team like Shaq and Penny's Magic in conference playoffs....   -Jordan did it with less help. Pippen was a great player. Without MJ though, his legacy wouldn't be what it is today. That's just the damn truth. MJ never had more than one more all-star on the roster with him. Lebron has had multiple all-stars on the roster with him on multiple occasions (not this year......lol). In MJ's 6 championships, the ones in 1991 and 1998... he was the only all-star on the roster. Lebron has played with over 2x more all-stars in total (meaning if Lebron played with DWade 4 years, counting it as 4) than Jordan did. In 2 of Lebron's championships, he was one of 3 all-stars on the roster. He's lost multiple finals as one of 3 all-stars on the roster. I'll say that this is the closest of my arguments because MJ had some great role players like Rodman on his teams, but Lebron has had more all-stars by a long shot. And he's had probably the greatest 3pt shooter in NBA history on his roster (who bailed out their team after Lebron's missed 3 in the playoffs...). You could make a case for Reggie or Drazen because those guys actually had to work to get open for his shots unlike Allen who was more of a spot shooter, and because a guy like Reggie was his team's #1 guy, so he was stuck with the best defender, but if I had to have one guy to make a 3, it would be Ray Allen, and most people wouldn't disagree with that. Not even a Pacers fan like me lol.  -MJ was more clutch. Goes back to killer instinct. At the end of the game, MJ was going to have the ball. Period. 50% on game tying/go-ahead shots inside of 24 seconds remaining. You literally cannot make the argument that Lebron was more clutch. At all. For a while, he wasn't even the most clutch player ON HIS TEAM, let alone in the NBA, or in NBA HISTORY ffs.... Kyrie would often be the one with the ball on the last possession and Lebron wouldn't even touch it. Why? Because Kyrie was more clutch. Lebron has made the "right play" in the clutch (passing) just as MJ did to Kerr, etc. But Lebron has also been bailed out by Kyrie, Ray Allen (missed shot, rebound gets kicked to Allen who saves game).   -MJ never carried the stigma of "disappearing" in the 4th quarter. It's almost unfathomable to call someone the GOAT who literally has spent MULTIPLE YEARS OF HIS CAREER getting lambasted for disappearing in the 4th quarter as Lebron's career has seen. Speaking of disappearing, MJ also never got out-played through an entire finals series by a past-his-prime role player like Jason Terry...   I could continue on from the viewpoint of someone who's spent hours and hours watching both, something it's become very clear that a huge number of Lebron>Jordan'ers are too young to say. I think Lebron is right there in the discussion with the best players of all time. He'd be on my all-time starting 5 without question. I'm not trying to trash the dude. He's probably my 2nd or 3rd favorite player in the NBA right now. I thoroughly enjoy watching him. I respect the hell out of what he's done on and off the court. He's super intelligent in both respects. He's a tremendous role model (something Jordan can't exactly claim lol). And he's one of the best to ever lace them up.  ... but he ain't MJ. I rest my case.

Okay I don't want to make it sound like I'm just comparing stats, but Jordan literally is the team. When he retired for the first time,  the Bulls were trash. When he returned they won like 3 finals in a row. Lebron is an outstanding athlete don't get me wrong and will be labeled as one of the greatest of all time, but Jordan has never lost a Final he played in, and literally. There is obvious proof that the Bulls were nothing without Jordan. Jordan didn't need any great teammates. As long as he had a shooter (which he did John Paxson and Steve Kerr) The Bulls were amazing just because of Jordan. Of course, this era of basketball is completely different from the era that Jordan played in, so you can't really compare. But just watching how the Bulls played with Jordan made everyone believe he is the GOAT of basketball, and arguably sports history. Just remember the Bulls had the worst seasons ever when Jordan first retired, and they won 3 in a row when he returned.

Michael Jordan definitely has had more impact on basketball but that is not the question at hand. The question is, who is the better player? 1. More rebounds per game 2. More assists 3. More scoring efficiency 4. More finals appearances (Jordan never made the finals without hall-of-fame-worthy Pippen) (Lebron took the trash old Cleveland team and the new trash Cleveland team whose third best player is JR Smith, to the finals) (Jordan had 3 all-nba defensive players on his team) 5. Lebron has more competition (no team in nba history has been as good as the warriors even before durant because 73-9>72-10)

Hate to lift your "worship LeBron James at all costs" shades, but Jordan had a competitive spirit unlike ANY we had ever seen before. Sorry, but when you take a sport to a professional level like these 2 men did, it's all about competitiveness. Not letting your physical advantages over pretty much everyone you played guide you to victory. Not relying on the refs' calls or no-calls to get you free points. Not playing an individual game, as opposed to a team game, by standing in the backcourt like a buffoon after getting some lame dunk that anyone his size could do, rather than hustling back on defense. LeBron is not even CLOSE to the level of Jordan, and that's a fact. He's probably the softest 6'8", 250 pound guy you will ever see. And you're seriously gonna talk about REFS? Like the refs don't favor LeBron as well? I'm sorry, but that is ABSOLUTE bullshit. Save it for the dicksucking session. Have you seen all the travels and shitty flops that went his way? Jordan would never do that, not even in today's game. It's just a level that a man like him would never stoop to. And LeBron isn't exactly what I'd like to call a "role model." He is cocky, definitely not as cocky as MJ, but cocky enough to make me steer clear of modeling any part of my life after him. Also, you're talking like literally the only thing a team needs to be successful is LeBron. Last time I checked, LeBron didn't do so well until he "took his talents to south beach," and got paired with 2 NBA greats at the time. I wonder why that is. Put LeBron on a team with shitty teammates (not one with Kyrie Irving and Kevin Love who both bailed him out numerous times, not one with Dwyane Wade, Chris Bosh, and even Ray Allen who bailed him out in that one finals series against the Spurs), and you get about the same result that Jordan got, early in each of their respective careers. I'm not at all saying LeBron isn't a great player, he's definitely one of the best we've ever seen, but to say that he's above Jordan is just insane.

Lifelong NE Ohio Cleveland fan here. I was on vacation in Zion National Park when this game was on. I was in my hotel room glued to the screen, enjoying adult beverages the whole game while my wife napped from the hike we finished earlier. I told her when she woke up that if the Cavs won, I was going to sprint from our 2nd floor room at the Hampton Inn out to the pool, do a front flip into the pool while chanting "Let's Go Cavs!" When that buzzer struck zero, I shot out of the room like an overweight bullet. I fulfilled my promise, but the poolgoers weren't impressed. I only got one cheer from a young kid who knew what was up. Tough crowd. Must've been a bunch of Warriors fans, lol. I'll never forget that moment. Special time to be a CLE sports fan! Funny to think that at dinner the night before I came across a family of Warriors fans when out for dinner. They called me out with my Cavs hat. I told the guy, "Mark my words, the Cavs will win by 4 tomorrow." Never would I have thought that prediction would've came true, no joke! I hope he was thinking of our conversation from the night before when he was watching the final moments of the game. Just my little story from this game... Ohio native on a Western US vacation who had to watch game 7 of the finals in his Springdale, UT hotel room. I was in Colorado for the game 6 comeback to force a game 7. Was a great summer! No matter how this series plays out, I'll never forget the 2016 championship.
This will never get old. One of the best finals game ever. Watching this still gives me goosebumps.

C'mon he didn't ruin a goddamn thing.  I am a lifelong Cavs fan and free agency is the nature of the business. The fact that it is a matter of debate who the real GOAT is, says more than anything about Lebron James. He is SO good, that it makes people uncertain if MJ still is the best to ever play the game. Now thats what proves that LBJ is the greatest of all times. Well, more precisely, I think that MJ and Lebron are the 2 greatest. They can't really be compared to one another because they both have brought something different to the court. But something unique, something that no one ever has. Lebron is the greatest leader, the greatest at the rim, the greatest overall player. He's presence on the court brings fear into the opposing team's heart, they know, that they can lose even if they lead by 25. Lebron brings out the best of his teammates on the court, they become a better shooter, a better defender, their game IQ rises. He passes the ball a lot, thats why his score avarage is worse than Jordan's. If he was just as selfish as Mj was, he could score 50points per game in his prime and I think also now he could do similar.. period. he can't be stopped at the rim he is a fine shooter and further more he still improves. His 3 point stats are the best so far this year. Ladies and Gentlemen Lebron James still gets better at the age of 33. And one more thing. His coaches ALWAYS SUCKED, MJ had the best coaches ever!! Lebron did it all by himself from day fucking one in the NBA!!! LET THAT SINK IN. All this achievements I have just told u guys, entitles Lebron fucking James to be on the same page with Michael Jordan. MJ has the killer instinct but Lebron James' heart is in the game all the time. MJ's greatness resided in his unmatchable grind and psycopethic competing fetish, while James' greatness is that he is driven by his heart. They are BOTH the number 1 players to ever play the game. U can not be better than Jordan. He is a God. But so is James. They are tied on the first place. Period. I don't care that MJ has more rings, because that is not what define's who the greatest is. The only thing that matters is the impact u make on court. nothing else. Thats how u become the greatest. lets imagine if u were in a team for ten 10 years winning 10 rings, but u're scoring avg was 7 each game. u still have 10 rings but u haven't made impact. u haven't earned the love of a whole world.
